title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
Australiaâ€™s 2019â€“20 â€œBlack Summerâ€ killed 34 people, destroyed thousands of homes, and caused major environmental damage.
This post asks a simple, public-facing question:

> Has human-driven climate change increased the chance of extreme fire weather in south-east Australia?
Researchers comparing todayâ€™s climate with a pre-industrial world find that the chance of an extreme Fire Weather Index (FWI) season is now about 30% higher.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
Data Description
The study integrates both observations and model experiments

ERA5 Reanalysis (1979â€“2020) â€“ temperature, rainfall and drought indices (Hersbach et al., 2019).

Bureau of Meteorology Fire Weather Index (FWI) â€“ the key indicator of bushfire danger (Dowdy 2018).

Climate models (CMIP5/6 ensembles) â€“ simulations with and without greenhouse gases to separate human influence (van Oldenborgh et al., 2021).

An â€œextreme seasonâ€ was defined as any year with a seasonal maximum FWI â‰¥ 2019â€“20.
Event probabilities were estimated using extreme-value fits for both climates; the Probability Ratio (PR) = current / pre-industrial risk.
Below is a simple visualisation of this idea (not real data but representative of their result).

library(ggplot2)
df <- data.frame(pr = 1.3, lo = 1.1, hi = 1.6)
ggplot(df, aes(x="PR")) +
  geom_col(aes(y=pr), fill="#006DAE") +
  geom_errorbar(aes(ymin=lo, ymax=hi), width=0.15) +
  coord_cartesian(ylim=c(0,2)) +
  labs(y="Current / Pre-industrial risk", x=NULL) +
  theme_minimal(base_size=13)







FigureÂ 1: Estimated Probability Ratio (PR) for an extreme FWI season under current vs pre-industrial climate.

title: Has Climate Change Raised the Risk of Extreme Bushfire Weather in Australia?
text:
ğŸŒ Data and Findings
The study used multiple independent data sources:

ERA5 Reanalysis (1979â€“2020) â€” records of temperature, rainfall, humidity, and wind (Hersbach et al., 2019)

Bureau of Meteorology Fire Weather Index (FWI) â€” a measure of daily bushfire danger (Dowdy 2018)

Climate-model ensembles (CMIP5/6) â€” simulations comparing current and pre-industrial climate worlds (van Oldenborgh et al., 2021)

Together, these sources reveal a clear upward shift in fire-weather risk.
Across all datasets, extreme FWI seasons are roughly 30% more likely in the present climate, and extreme heat events occur about twice as often, while dryness signals remain weak or uncertain.
